content: I think I need to take a 130s level math class in the fall for my concentration requirements. first check if thats needed, then tell me all the fall options and what's easiest (by hours needed)

# Math 130s Requirement for Mathematics Concentration

## Concentration Requirement Confirmation

Yes, as a Mathematics concentrator at Harvard, you do need to take at least one course at the 130 level or higher to fulfill your concentration requirements. Since you've already taken MATH 121, a 130-level course would be the next appropriate step in your academic progression.

## Fall 2025 Options (Ranked by Workload)

Based on the workload data provided, here are the 130-level math courses available in Fall 2025, ranked from lowest to highest workload:

### 1. **MATH 136 - Differential Geometry** (Easiest Option)
- **Instructor:** Oliver Knill
- **Mean Hours per Week:** 6.1 hours (significantly lower than other options)
- **Q Score:** 4.25/5.0 (well-rated)
- **Description:** Introduction to Riemannian geometry focusing on curves and surfaces in space.
- **Student Comment:** "This class is a lot of fun and a good class to fulfill the 130s requirement in the Math concentration!"

### 2. **MATH 131 - Topological Spaces and Fundamental Group**
- **Instructor:** Michael Hopkins
- **Mean Hours per Week:** 10.8 hours
- **Q Score:** 4.56/5.0 (highest rated of fall options)
- **Description:** Introduction to abstract topological spaces and algebraic topology.
- **Note:** This is more challenging but very well-rated. Students mention it gets significantly harder in the second half of the semester.

## Alternative Options (Not in Fall 2025)

If you're willing to wait until Spring 2026, here are other 130-level courses with their workload data:

- **MATH 132 - Differential Topology:** 10.1 hours/week, Q Score 4.18/5.0
- **MATH 130 - Classical Geometry:** 10.3 hours/week, Q Score 2.00/5.0
- **MATH 137 - Algebraic Geometry:** 10.0 hours/week, Q Score 4.28/5.0

## Recommendation

**MATH 136 (Differential Geometry)** is clearly your best option if workload is your primary concern. At 6.1 hours per week, it requires approximately 40% less time than the other 130-level courses. It also has a good Q Score of 4.25/5.0, and student comments indicate it's a fun and accessible way to fulfill the 130s requirement.

If you're looking for the highest-rated course and don't mind the extra ~4.7 hours per week, MATH 131 might be worth considering, as it has the highest Q Score of 4.56/5.0.

Would you like more specific information about either of these courses or their prerequisites?

# MATH 121 - Linear Algebra

## Course Information

I see you're inquiring about MATH 121, which is already listed in your courses taken. Here's the detailed information about this course:

### Basic Details
- **Instructor:** John Cain
- **Term:** Spring 2026
- **Course Level:** 100-level

### Course Description
This is a second course in linear algebra, with an emphasis on understanding linear algebra at a more abstract level and learning to read and write proofs. Topics include real and complex vector spaces, linear transformations, and eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

### Ratings
- **Overall Course Mean:** 4.3/5.0 (This is considered a very good rating)
- **Mean Hours per Week:** Not available in the data provided

### Requirements
- **Anti-requisite:** Not to be taken in addition to Mathematics 22a, 23a, 25a, or 55a

## Student Feedback

Students have shared some interesting perspectives on this course:
- "Very open/exploratory course. You can tell that Dylan REALLY cares about his students. I walked away from the class learning more about my relationship with math and learning. The class could have been better with more structure but it was what I needed for the semester. It is a very easy going course."
- "Take Math 121 :)"
- "If you take this course, be sure to hold yourself accountable. Because of its looser structure, it is easy to allow yourself to fall a bit behind."

## Note
According to your student profile, you've already taken MATH 121. This information is useful context for understanding why you might have been considering MATH 13X courses for your concentration requirements in your previous question.

Is there specific information about MATH 121 you're looking for, or would you like to know how it relates to the 130-level courses we discussed earlier?

courseData.description: This is a second course in linear algebra, with an emphasis on understanding linear algebra at a more abstract level and learning to read and write proofs. Topics include real and complex vector spaces, linear transformations, and eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
courseData.subject: Mathematics
courseData.course_requirements: Anti-req: Not to be taken in addition to Mathematics 22a, 23a or 25a or 55a.
courseData.recommended_prep: Mathematics 19b or 21b or an equivalent background in mathematics.
courseData.comments: ["Very open/exploratory course. you can tell that Dylan REALLY cares about his students. I walked away from the class learning more about my relationship with math and learning. The class could have been better with more structure but it was what I needed for the semester. It is a very easy going course","Take Math 121 :)","If you take this course, be sure to hold yourself accountable. Because of its looser structure, it is easy to allow yourself to fall a bit behind.","This class is what you make of it – you can do as much or as little as you like to get by. If you do wish to do more, it's certainly possible and can be a great mathematics course in this regard, especially with experience writing proofs.","This is a great intro to proofs! The topics are interesting, but I strongly recommend taking Math 21b beforehand.","This is a very difficult class that is very chill if you want it to be. ONLY take this class if you really want to learn math AND are VERY self–guided.","With Dylan Wilson, there is opportunity to explore if you have the time and motivation. There are no grades, which means that you have to be *really* self–driven to make the class what you want. I did not, and so I feel like I did not get much out of the class. I will be self–studying MIT's 18.06 Linear Algebra class to make up for my lack of foundational linear alg knowledge.\n\nWhen I tried to pset with peers, many politely declined because they valued the class as lower relative to their other classes. Thus, the lack of grading in this class RELATIVE to other classes means that there was a lack of community through struggle (lol). I wish I got to know my peers better!! They seemed like cool people.","This class is much more proof–based than something like Math 21b, and I would recommend having 21b under your belt beforehand, because without it, material in proof format can seem much more confusing. Dylan was great and super helpful, though not sure what this class under another professor would be like.","If you have any interest in upper level mathematics, you should take this class. It will give you all the necessary tools you need to pursue anything else you would choose to in the department.","If Dylan Wilson is teaching this class – take it. Best professor I've had in terms of actually prioritizing learning over completionism. The course material is still a little dry – it's proof–based linear algebra, but Dylan makes up for it.","Dylan is an AMAZING professor. I have never felt safe in a math classroom to inquire and genuinely learn until I took Dylan's class/had him as a professor. He really emphasizes learning to learn instead of for an output (grade). He is also great at explaining difficult concepts, and some things I didn't understand in 21b suddenly clicked in 121. Be wary of who is teaching this though––experience is highly dependent on the instructor.","This class has a ton of flexibility. If you can manage things on your own without outside structure, then take this class! Dylan is super nice and puts an emphasis on learning purely for learning's sake. If you're not great with a lot of flexibility and need external structure, don't take this. It's very self guided, so you won't be able to learn just with what's given.","Take this class; it will definitely expand your understanding in general beyond math.","It is probably not worth your time.","Great class"]

# MATH 121 - Linear Algebra

## Course Information

Based on the information available, here are the details about MATH 121:

### Basic Details
- **Course:** MATH 121 - Linear Algebra
- **Instructor:** John Cain
- **Term:** Spring 2026
- **Department:** Mathematics

### Course Description
This is a second course in linear algebra, with an emphasis on understanding linear algebra at a more abstract level and learning to read and write proofs. Topics include real and complex vector spaces, linear transformations, and eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

### Ratings
- **Overall Course Mean:** 4.3/5.0 (This is considered a very good rating)
- **Mean Hours per Week:** Not available in the data

### Requirements
- **Anti-requisites:** Not to be taken in addition to Mathematics 22a, 23a, 25a, or 55a

## Student Feedback
The course has received positive feedback from students:
- "Very open/exploratory course. You can tell that Dylan REALLY cares about his students. I walked away from the class learning more about my relationship with math and learning. The class could have been better with more structure but it was what I needed for the semester. It is a very easy going course."
- "Take Math 121 :)"
- "If you take this course, be sure to hold yourself accountable. Because of its looser structure, it is easy to allow yourself to fall a bit behind."

## Note
According to your student profile, you've already taken MATH 121. This course serves as a foundation for the 130-level mathematics courses we discussed in your previous question.

Would you like any specific information about how MATH 121 relates to the 130-level courses you're considering for your concentration requirements?

If you do wish to do more, it's certainly possible and can be a great mathematics course in this regard, especially with experience writing proofs.","This is a great intro to proofs! The topics are interesting, but I strongly recommend taking Math 21b beforehand.","This is a very difficult class that is very chill if you want it to be. ONLY take this class if you really want to learn math AND are VERY self–guided.","With Dylan Wilson, there is opportunity to explore if you have the time and motivation. There are no grades, which means that you have to be *really* self–driven to make the class what you want. I did not, and so I feel like I did not get much out of the class. I will be self–studying MIT's 18.06 Linear Algebra class to make up for my lack of foundational linear alg knowledge.\n\nWhen I tried to pset with peers, many politely declined because they valued the class as lower relative to their other classes. Thus, the lack of grading in this class RELATIVE to other classes means that there was a lack of community through struggle (lol). I wish I got to know my peers better!! They seemed like cool people.","This class is much more proof–based than something like Math 21b, and I would recommend having 21b under your belt beforehand, because without it, material in proof format can seem much more confusing. Dylan was great and super helpful, though not sure what this class under another professor would be like.","If you have any interest in upper level mathematics, you should take this class. It will give you all the necessary tools you need to pursue anything else you would choose to in the department.","If Dylan Wilson is teaching this class – take it. Best professor I've had in terms of actually prioritizing learning over completionism. The course material is still a little dry – it's proof–based linear algebra, but Dylan makes up for it.","Dylan is an AMAZING professor. I have never felt safe in a math classroom to inquire and genuinely learn until I took Dylan's class/had him as a professor. He really emphasizes learning to learn instead of for an output (grade). He is also great at explaining difficult concepts, and some things I didn't understand in 21b suddenly clicked in 121. Be wary of who is teaching this though––experience is highly dependent on the instructor.","This class has a ton of flexibility. If you can manage things on your own without outside structure, then take this class! Dylan is super nice and puts an emphasis on learning purely for learning's sake. If you're not great with a lot of flexibility and need external structure, don't take this. It's very self guided, so you won't be able to learn just with what's given.","Take this class; it will definitely expand your understanding in general beyond math.","It is probably not worth your time.","Great class"]

# MATH 121 - Linear Algebra

## Course Information

Here's the information about MATH 121 based on the available data:

### Basic Details
- **Course:** MATH 121 - Linear Algebra
- **Instructor:** John Cain
- **Term:** Spring 2026
- **Department:** Mathematics

### Course Description
This is a second course in linear algebra, with an emphasis on understanding linear algebra at a more abstract level and learning to read and write proofs. Topics include real and complex vector spaces, linear transformations, and eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

### Ratings
- **Overall Course Mean:** 4.3/5.0 (This indicates a well-rated course)
- **Mean Hours per Week:** Not available in the data

### Requirements
- **Anti-requisites:** Not to be taken in addition to Mathematics 22a, 23a, 25a, or 55a

## Student Feedback
- "Very open/exploratory course. You can tell that Dylan REALLY cares about his students. I walked away from the class learning more about my relationship with math and learning. The class could have been better with more structure but it was what I needed for the semester. It is a very easy going course."
- "Take Math 121 :)"
- "If you take this course, be sure to hold yourself accountable. Because of its looser structure, it is easy to allow yourself to fall a bit behind."

## Note
According to your student profile, you have already taken MATH 121. This course serves as important preparation for higher-level mathematics courses that would fulfill your concentration requirements.

Would you like information about how MATH 121 connects to specific 130-level courses, or are you looking for different information about this course?
